docs.lead_paragraph: The first big fight over the Senate Finance Committee's health care legislation erupted Tuesday night: a rollicking brawl over a deal that the Obama administration cut with the pharmaceutical industry to achieve $80 billion in savings on drug costs over 10 years, money that would help pay for the legislation.

headline.main: Democrats Spar Among Themselves Over PhRMA Deal

docs.abstract: A deal between Obama and the drug industry worries some Democrats
docs.snippet: A deal between Obama and the drug industry worries some Democrats

byline.original: By DAVID HERSZENHORN and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: In the discussion over ways to make health care more affordable, Senator Max Baucus of Montana and other health policy wonks have mostly talked about greater premium subsidies based on income.

headline.main: In Health Care Premiums, Who Gets a Subsidy?

docs.abstract: Plenty of premium subsidies are implicit in the Baucus plan for health care reform -- for, among others, big families, young women and old men.
docs.snippet: Plenty of premium subsidies are implicit in the Baucus plan for health care reform -- for, among others, big families, young women and old men.

docs.lead_paragraph: Corrected| 6:33 p.m. An earlier version of this article used a financial example that misstated the hypothetical family's legal liability. That family would not have faced a $1,500 financial penalty. The article has been updated with an example in which the family would incur the fine.

headline.main: Contrarian View: The Proposed Fine for Going Without Insurance Is Too Low

docs.abstract: Some have criticized the Baucus health care proposal as punitive because it would fine people who did not sign up for health insurance. But a Wall Street health care analyst says the fines are too low.
docs.snippet: Some have criticized the Baucus health care proposal as punitive because it would fine people who did not sign up for health insurance. But a Wall Street health care analyst says the fines are too low.

docs.lead_paragraph: Feeling sorry for insurance company executives? Then you can weep along with a new online ad.

headline.main: Hollywood Reaches Out to Insurers, and Slaps Them

docs.abstract: Celebrities offer, um, succor to beleaguered insurance company executives.
docs.snippet: Celebrities offer, um, succor to beleaguered insurance company executives.

docs.lead_paragraph: George Halvorson, the chief executive of one of the nation's most respected health care systems, Kaiser Permanente, says he is hopeful that all the sausage-making in Washington will succeed in squeezing out a law.

headline.main: Kaiser Permanente's Chief Optimistic About Health Overhaul Effort

docs.abstract: The head of Kaiser Permanente is optimistic that a health care overhaul will pass this time.
docs.snippet: The head of Kaiser Permanente is optimistic that a health care overhaul will pass this time.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a sign of escalating tension on Capitol Hill, the Republican leader in the Senate, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, accused Democrats and the Obama administration on Tuesday of trying to muzzle critics of their proposed health care legislation.

headline.main: Senate Republican Leader Accuses Democrats of Muzzling Critics

docs.abstract: In a sign of escalating tensions on Capitol Hill, Senator Mitch McConnell angrily accuses Democrats of stifling opposition to proposed health care legislation.
docs.snippet: In a sign of escalating tensions on Capitol Hill, Senator Mitch McConnell angrily accuses Democrats of stifling opposition to proposed health care legislation.

headline.main: Q&A: Swine Flu Restrictions in Japan

docs.abstract: "My friends and I are planning to travel to Japan in October. With swine flu on the horizon and expected to peak that month, is it possible that American travelers will be quarantined?"
docs.snippet: "My friends and I are planning to travel to Japan in October. With swine flu on the horizon and expected to peak that month, is it possible that American travelers will be quarantined?"

docs.lead_paragraph: We've said it before and we'll say it again: affordability of insurance is the central question in the health care debate on Capitol Hill.

headline.main: Baucus Proposes New Limits on Insurance Premiums

docs.abstract: Senator Max Baucus today proposed limiting the cost of insurance to 12 percent of income for moderate-income households. One question: Is that as good as the deal he's getting?
docs.snippet: Senator Max Baucus today proposed limiting the cost of insurance to 12 percent of income for moderate-income households. One question: Is that as good as the deal he's getting?

docs.lead_paragraph: This is part of a series of primers on some of the basic elements of the health care legislation circulating in Congress. An earlier post explained the concept of insurance exchanges.

headline.main: Good As Gold? A Primer on Comparing Health Plans

docs.abstract: As part of a series of primers about some of the basic elements of the health care legislation circulating in Congress, this article considers how to compare health insurance offerings.
docs.snippet: As part of a series of primers about some of the basic elements of the health care legislation circulating in Congress, this article considers how to compare health insurance offerings.

docs.lead_paragraph: Opening statements are under way in the Senate Finance Committee's mark-up of proposed health care legislation.

headline.main: Senators Stake Out Positions on the Baucus Plan

docs.abstract: Opening statements from Senate Finance Committee members reveal sharp differences on the Baucus proposal.
docs.snippet: Opening statements from Senate Finance Committee members reveal sharp differences on the Baucus proposal.
